12 oz bottle, poured into a nonic pint at ~40 degrees F.

A: Pours a crystal-clear orange-gold, much like a burnished copper. Forms a decent finger head of foam that seems just off-white with a hint of orange, and dissipates fairly quickly. Carbonation is visible as fairly large bubbles clinging to the bottom of the glass, occasionally shooting for the surface.

S: The aroma reminds me of a caramel biscuit with crumbled cracker topping. Some faint notes of spice and earth roll about in the scent as well.

T: The first sip opens almost exactly as the nose suggests, a blend of crackery and biscuity malt with some light caramel drizzle across the top. That is swiftly joined by a heavy dose of earthy, spicy hop presence, covering the malt presence with a thick layer of freshly turned soil from a field used to grow a mix of white, green, and black peppercorns. Said hop presence maintains all the way through the finish, where the malt returns to a little more prominence as a peppered biscuit, and into the aftertaste, where it lingers overlong.

M: This is a smooth, medium-carbonated, fairly thin-bodied beer. If it werent for the hop presence, I could probably crush them down quickly.

O: While I love a good märzen, particularly the Ayinger (ironic given where Dan Carey spent a few months apprenticing), I primarily love them for showcasing malt with minimal hop presence. This beer stands that relationship on its head for me, and comes very close to triggering my supertaster reaction to hop-forward beer. While I can still drink it, and even enjoy some aspects of it, it is pretty far from my favorite märzen. If youre following any of my reviews because youre also a supertaster, you may want to give this one a miss.

12 oz bottle purchased at Woodmans in Onalaska, Wisconsin. The pour is clear golden copper with a two inch off white head that falls noisily.  The aroma is sweet cereal grain, caramel, and light grass and earth. The taste is grain, cereal malt, faint caramel sweet, then a bit of the grass in the drier finish. The palate is medium to light bodied, active carbonation and a slightly dirty sweet grass finish. Decent Oktoberfest, though I guess I expected a bit more from New Glarus.

Bottle. The aroma is strong malt. The taste is really smooth, but a little thin. A decent octoberfest.

This is just an ok brew. It really is lacking depth and flavor. It may have lots of malt but I feel that this is overpowering and underwhelming in flavor profile.

Light red color and very clear.  Single finger head faded quick.  Mouth is thin.  Aroma is spicey and malty.  Taste is malty.  Lots of classic Marzen notes.  I found this to be a a little muted though.

Pours golden/lt amber with a medium lt tan head.  Aroma has straw, grass, and just a touch of dry leaves and caramel.  Flavor follows suit...almost a hint of chocolate...like a hint of tootsie roll.  Mouthfeel is medium and creamy with an earthy/grassy/lt roasted finish.
Pours a dark red, amber color, with medium head.  Aromas of roast, nuts, barley.  Flavors of roast, nuts, hops, barley, Crisp finish.  Light bitter aftertaste.
Reddish pour with a light tan head. Aroma is caramel malt and so ecru spends. Barley and caramel notes. Slightly sweet but clean. Good.
One of the more decent Oktoberfest beers I have tasted for someone who does not have an Oktoberfest palate...

My first Oktoberfest of the season! Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a Deschutes snifter.

A: Pours an amber color, a little on the dark side, with a nice 1.5 finger white head that sticks around for a while. Leaves some nice bubbly lace on the way down.

S: Big on the malts with some little spices coming around. Pretty typical of the style.

T: Just big malts and some lager-like qualities to it. No really spiced notes or anything. Not the biggest fan.

M: Light to medium bodied. Crisp and clean with a smooth swallow. Very drinkable.

O: Wasnt that impressed with this one. Big malts and nothing else. Very one dimensional.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-11-2011

Pours a clear deep copper color with a one finger tan foamy head. Head fades quick and doesnt leave much lacing.  Aromas are of sweet malts and a little earthy grass or hay. Flavors are big roasted malts with a nice sweetness. Not much hops for balance, this one is all about the malts. Not my favorite New Glarus beer, but a decent seasonal Octoberfest brew.

Bottle from Woodmans in the Falls. Pours a clear copper color with a white head around the rim. Cannot really coax any lacing. Aroma has sweet fruits, malted milk, hay and a vanilla-ish note. Taste is of sweet toffee, pitted fruits and bread. Smoother than the aroma and actually a bit syrupy. Finishes sweetly and fairly short. Ive had worse marzens.
36cl, no mention of ABV, American brew, from De Bierkoning Amsterdam, complex brew, malty/sweet and slightly spicy, balanced, clear, small head, nice brew
UPDATED: OCT 2, 2012 Very bready and nutty. Slightest initial burst of pilsnerish grain and grass. Not bad for the style but the body could be more.
Easy drinking Octoberfest but seems a little light. Im sure that was intentional, great brewers at new glarus, good for a session style octoberfest but I prefer a little more heft.

Pours crystal clear orange with a creamy white head.  Malt aroma with some German yeast notes.  Sweet and malty with no hop bitterness. The finish is fairly dry.  Rich creamy mouthfeel with a medium body and carbonation.  Very enjoyable Octoberfest that is true to style.
pours an amber red with about an inch of white head, scent of yeast, roasted malt.  the flavor was grassy, malty, hay, spice

Enjoyed on tap at Palm Tavern. Pours an amber brown with a medium white head that clings to the glass - exceptional appearance. Little to no smell but makes up for it on taste: hot cereal, oats, hay, and almost exactly like the taste of warm shredded wheat cereal. The aftertaste is of breakfast malt. Surprising and delicious.

Head isnt exactly what I expected, seemed to pour a bit flat.  Plenty of carbonation.  Nice light roast on the malts, theres some honey and apple aroma.  Pours like dark apple juice, but drinks much better.  Definitely tastes like a traditional Octoberfest, nice mouthfeel, rich malts.  Drinks really well for a style that can leave a lot to be desired.  Finishes nice and dry, with long lasting aftertaste.  Would definitely drink again.
UPDATED: OCT 9, 2012 Has a nice sweet taste, nice little bitter, some sweet caramel with a rather dry finish.
One of my favorite beers and a sure sign of the start of fall. Great malt character and balanced hops. Like angel tears in a bottle.

Nice thick white head, redish amber in color.  Faint roasted malt smell.  Inital blast of sweet, roasted malt, with l=slight hint of hops/spice.  Nice clean lager with a smooth finish.  Very tasty...worth a trip into Wisconsin to grab.
One of my favorite oktoberfests. Variety of flavors and nice balance of light and filling. New glarus never disappoints

Mild malt aroma.  Nice white head.  Lighter in color and flavor than some overdone American Oktos.  Kind of like a good balance between a German and American oktoberfest.  One of my favorite beers.  If youre outside of Wisconsin trade for some!

My favorite Marzen. Auburn color with slight lace. Caramel. New Glarus is Wisconsin's best craft brewer!

Of the 25-30 different Oktos Ive tried, this is probably my favorite. Delicious beer, with great smooth body and nice balance of flavor. I look forward to having quite a few of these this fall. Another great offering from New Glarus!

Bottle, pours clear orange-amber with finger of white head. Not much lacing. Nose is biscuit malt, nuttiness, hint of fall spice. A bit thin on the taste, but the bready notes complement the subtle hop presence nicely. Endlessly drinkable.
The best Oktoberfest beer Ive tried. Crisp clean and not heavy like some Oktoberfests.

Originally reviewed: 10/23/09. Pours a clear pale orange. This is a lot lighter than I expected. A nice inch-sized white head rests on top. Decent retention. Smells of nuts, bread, butterscotch, and a bit of mineral twang. 

The body on this is a little on the light side. A bit more watery than I would like, but still decent. Nice slight bittering hops at the forefront, but has a nice crisp finish of fresh bread and toasted malts. This is really good. Some of the characteristics could be tweaked a bit, but its good where it counts: flavor.

Big thanks to BeerFMAndy for getting a box of New Glarus out to me. Served in a New Glarus taster glass.

Pours a clear deep amber/copper color with a nice white head and some spotty lacing on the way down. The nose has a good bit of amber and bready malt with a touch of caramel sweetness. Some earthy hops lingering in the background. The flavor is quite malty with a bit of hops cutting through the finish. Medium body. Very nice.

Pretty run of the mill October Fest beer.  Tastes like nmBecks October Fest.  No head, great color.  Sweet notes up front and a lingering sweetness on the palate.

Bottle.  Pours slightly hazy orange with thin, fizzy white head; decent retention and spare lacing.  Aroma is caramel malt, toffee, wheat, light citrus fruit, grassy hops, and light spice.  Flavor is malt dominate with faint hops and fruit esters; sweet finish.  Medium body and carbonation with low warmth.

Bottle split with Andrew. Pours an amber body with decent white head. Aroma is sweet, lots of barley, wheat and spice. Mouthfeel is thin to medium with similar notes in the flavor plus some roasted malts. Nothing amazing, but a solid brew.

transparent gold, thin white ring, large-bubbled white head. Nose shows considerable dirty grain with lightly milky with considerable wheat. Flavor is grain, sawdust front, lemon mid, followed by doughy marshmallow sweetness in the finish.

Bottle pours deep amber with a white head. Aroma is primarily malt driven with notes of toffee/caramel, light nuts, and a touch of red fruit. Flavor shows the same with a bready malt profile, light earth, and a nice amount of toast. Overall body is moderate and soft. Not complicated by any means, but still fairly solid with a good balance.

Bottle thanks to Weihenheizen! Thanks! Poured into a footed Pilsner glass. Appearance is a dark copper, almost amber, with a thick crop of beige foam resting atop the beer. Lacing is thick and webby. Aroma is toasty, and caramel-y. I get an almost nutty aroma in here as well. Taste is a bit vegetal and earthy, but the malty goodness finds a way to overpower that. Carrot cake keeps running through my mind as I drink this, minus the icing, anyway. Thin on the palate, even for the style. lingering butterscotch-y aftertaste.

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with Tom and his buddy. Pours light orange with a sparse, creamy white head. Some spotty lacing. Aroma of apples, dry champagne grapes, honey, and some odd hints of peanut butter and moist, dank basement must. Medium to thinner bodied with a very smooth, gentle palate. Tastes very similar to apple juice with some pumpkin notes and a bit of subtle spice. Decent.
12 ounce bottle, that poured a yellow orange color.  Aromas of sweet malt, and a touch of caramel.  Flavor is much like the aroma with a nnice balance of caramel and malt, and made it real enjoyable.

Refrigerated bottle compliments of Joe Peesie, poured into a shaker.  Pours clear copper with one inch off-white head that dissapates quickly.  Very little lacing, light body, and watery texture.  Taste is clearn barley malt, slight off taste, and crip finish.  Ayinger Octoberfest is better.
thanks Patr for sharing-12oz bottle-pours an offwhite head with amber color.  Aroma is fruit, light/medium malt-caramel.  Taste is fruit/spice hops, light/medium malt-caramel.

When I first take a whiff, the aroma is that of a typical lager. As I sip, I notice that the aroma is more complex; the most prominent is a caramel malt, along with some wheaty malts and some dry hops. The palate is quite smooth. Satisfying beer, overall.

1. Look  A clear medium amber color Octoberfest with a very small white head.
2. Sniff  It has a big malty aroma.
3. Sip  This is medium bodied Octoberfest is full of flavor.  It has a tasty roasted malt flavor that is perfectly balanced with very delicate hop bitterness.
4. Another Look  This is an average looking Octoberfest with no lacing, but it has an excellent amber color that will keep you interested.
5. Evaluate  Overall, Staghorn Octoberfest is a delicious and very drinkable lager.  I particularly enjoy the sweet long lasting roasted malt flavor.  I would absolutely recommend this lager to everyone.

Golden orange pour,next to no head-quickly fizzeled.Very clear and bright, nice aroma of grain caramel light orange,nut ,smoke. Taste is nice and smooth with the same character.Clean mild citrus finish.This one seems lighter than 6%.Very good aroma and tasting marzen
12oz bottle from A.L. Nice smooth fest beer. Lots of sweet malts, but not overly caramel tasting. Tastes like some winter spices snuck in there too. Finish was o.k.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2016 Tap at Meridian Pint. The pour is a clear orange amber with a small, tan head. Little lace. Semi rocky appearance. Nose is muted- cherry juice, Vienna malt, mild toffee. Taste is a bit watery and slightly soapy- clean malt character. Very mild and chuggable with quenching lightness. Sessionable but not particularly special. 10/11/2011 6/3/6/4/13=3.2Tap at New Glarus. Clear amber pour with amazing foam. Flavor has excellent bready malt, juicy orange, excellent balance. Super drinkable. Easily the best oktoberfest Ive ever had.
Draft.  A decent enough fest beer, nice bitter pepper aroma, plain lager like taste.

2011 bottle from brewery. Pours Copper with white head. Aroma is grainy with corn mainly. Taste is Grain, Corn, slight nuttiness, very malty, slight amount of hops. The malts really steal the show, great malty flavor. Goes down really easy and finishes very clean, you can really pound these down. Great Oktoberfest beer!

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2012 Gabf. A touch hazy, golden appearance with a white head. Grassy hoppy, toasty, pale malty lager. Pretty crisp, toasty, pale golden malty lager flavor. Update: 2012 version seemed duller and more like a macro lager to me, though it was drinkable.

Bottle into pint glass in Madison.  Its a true Oktoberfest, somewhere between a light and a dark beer.  The spices are noticeable, but there arent too many distinguishing features.  Very drinkable, but not necessarily memorable.  Its a traditional autumn beer.

Aroma: bread and toast, slight sweetness, rich malts.  Pours amber with a  large white head, good retention and lots of lacing.  Very malty flavor, toast, clean, slight bitterness and hop flavor, faint sweetness up front with a fairly dry finish.  Medium body and carbonation.  Very tasty, solid brew.

Bottle to pint glass. Pour is amber in color with a white foamy head that fades to a film. Aroma is spiced clove tobacco and herbal malts. Taste is more spice like clove and herbal with some noticable yeast and bread. Palate is medium body with a fizzy slick dry finish. Very nice.
Light amber color with big white head.  Typical spicy malt aroma.  Taste is biscuity, spicy, caramel and toasty.  Rather light body.  Love the very biscuity-malt.  Very good.

Bottle from a kind soul. Pours a very attractive clear and orangey with a fluffy white head. Nose is toasty, light caramel and some faint noble hops. Quite crisp and clean. On tasting, a touch of caramel, but mostly toasty bread crusts. An interesting level of bitterness that works quite well. Lightly spicy as well. Really clean and refreshing. Great beer!

12 oz bottle I picked up at the brewery. Pours a translucent copper color with a big off-white head that has great retention. The aroma is mild with sweet malts and a touch or molasses. The flavor is more sweet malts, biscuit, almonds and cookie dough.  The palate is light and crisp (appropriate for the style) with soft carbonation. Finishes short and clean. Overall: Wow, very tasty Oktoberfest, very nice.

On tap. Pours a clear amber an off white head that dissipates completely. Aroma has notes of grain and hay with a bit of earthy grass notes. Flavor starts with grains and bread with some nuttiness and hay coming out.
12oz bottle. Pours a bright, copper color with a white head. Aroma is malty, bread, yeasty. Medium on the palate with soft carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, nutty, bread.
A very nice beer, but Oktoberfest style beers rarely top my personal list.  Cheers!

12oz bottle, has been in the fridge for some time, this is the last of a six pack purchased a while back. Brilliant clarity. Reddish, amber color with a small white head. Aroma is all about the malt. Lots of rich, melanodin-rich munich malt in the nose and very clean. The taste is malty throughout, with lots more melanodins in the flavor, perhaps a touch of spicy hops in the background and a clean, well balanced finish. This is a well executed, by the book, Octoberfest and it is just wonderful.
Bottle from back of beer frig...from earlier this winter....pour golden amber with very nice head and lacing.  Very smooth going down....reminds me of last Octoberfest in Milwaukee.....

Bottle pours yellow-amber with medium white frothy brief head.  Grassy aroma with slight hops and spice.  Taste initially sweet, light malts, grass, slight citrus and spice.  Clean finish with mild German hops.  Palate think but not watery, nice body and carbonation.  Overall OK to good.
POurs golden straw with notes of spice right off the bat.  These notes of light cloves and anise drive though the malty base that give it a nice fresh finish.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2016 Good attempt from NG. It did well at our Oktoberfest tasting (among 16 others). It is not an Oktoberfest though, more just like a light Dunkel bier, i guess maybe like the amber beers of Bamberg.

RERATE:
this is an okto i feel ive at least had once in most of th years in between this review. It landed in the middle of the pack when tasting 33 of them blind last year. First impression: I do not remember this beer being so light. This is way lighter than I remember it being. I swear it used to be waaay darker. This is a beutiful brew. The aroma is full-throttle. It starts with almsot a hint of smoke, intensley herbal and resinous noble hops, hint of vinegar on the nose, it is also fruity, almost figgy. Complex, bold, and non-traditional. The flavor is a suprise. This is nothing like what I remember this beer being. It is sweet, honey-like malt character, strawberry, lower bodied mouthfeel but a bit silky. Has a hint of diacetyl, comes of kind of zwickel-like with a minerally breadcrust finish. This is a surprise. This has to be a new recipe. A visceral and interesting deviation on the oktoberfestbier.

12 oz bottle from Woodmans. I wanted something lighter after four hours digging my car out of the snow, because Id carbed up on pretzels & hamburgers today. And finding this Oktoberfest on the shelves in January will not help its rating. Indeed, I caught oxidation as soon as I pooped the cap, but it went away. Still a whiff of skunk in my glass, but also a nose full of Vienna and light barley. Appearance is a bit light for the style, but its a nice clear beer. Taste is nice and smooth, with spicy German hops being delivered through the bubbles. Not much else to add, I just followed all the way down my glass.

12 oz bottle; pours crystal clear copper with thin white head fading quickly; stale oranges, dry malt, light candy syrup; drinks with thin texture and stale, dry malt; has some honey flavor in there too; drinks very smooth with crisp, dry finish; solid overall

Poured a nice clear reddish amber with a modest head that faded to lace rather quickly.  Aromas were primarily of malts with a slight sweetness.  Taste began with strong malts then quickly moving in to a hay hue before finishing with smooth moderate hoppiness.  Mouthfeel was decent but nothing outstanding.  Overall a nice amber Octoberfest that will be worth re-visiting in the future.
user_location: Town of Maple Creek, Wisconsin, USA

text: Bottle.  Smell of a heady, grainy malt, is followed by a beautiful amber color and pillowy head when poured into a glass.  A taste of thick bodied, caramel malts is finished by just a hint of hoppiness.  A fantastic Oktoberfest and beer.

Pours a mostly clear golden orange color and topped by a thick, foamy beige colored head that settles to a thin film and leaving skinny lines of lace on the glass. The aroma is that of sweet caramel malt, toasted nuts, cereal grains, and some floral hops. The flavor follows with the toasted cereal grains and sweet caramel malts up front followed by some toasted nuts, and some floral hop bitterness on the back end. Medium bodied with ample carbonation that leads to a clean, malty finish. A nice easy drinking beer, and solid for the style.
Amber-orange pour, frothy white head.  Aroma of yeast and malts.  Medium-thick body with a flavor of herbs and mild citrus, with some malts.
Orange amber pour. Aroma of grass and yeast. A lot of bread in the flavor with a very alcoholic finish.
aroma- bread, hay, leaves, sugar, apple. pours deep gold amber. taste is sweet bread, apple, hay, slight bitter finish.  palate is clean, crisp, lively carbonation, light body.

Bottle  Pours a clear golden with a froathy off white head.  The head disapates rapidly. No lacing to speak of.  Aroma is barley, some dough, roast, and hints of caramel.  has a good carbonation.  The flavor is okay but seems to lack real depth.  Has a watery texture.  The body is light to medium.  Has a very refreshing drinkability.  the finish is soft and a light aftertaste.  Very drinkable, just not outstanding.

Notes from September 2010

Ar: Medium roasted malt, bread dough.
Ap: Perfectly beautiful gold with a 1" head that dissipates slowly.
T: Honey sweetness with yeasty bread dough.  Not terribly complex but spot on.
P: Medium body.

O: Pretty good Oktoberfest, just really not my style.

12 oz. bottle from Discount Liquor in Milwaukee, WI.  Pale yellowish-orange pour with a very thin head.  Sweet lager-like aroma undistinguishable as an Oktoberfest vs. a regular lager.  The flavor is smooth and does not have the unpleasant bitterness that some lagers have.  Im not the best at describing this style of beer, and in fact most of the time I dont care for the style, but I will say this is certainly in the top tier of Marzen/Oktoberfest beers I have tried.

Bottle: Pours a nice clear golden with a modest head into a shaker; So the aroma was that roasted barley with a bit of floral bouquet but it also seemed a little off as well - i sensed the yeasts found in their belgian-themed brews, a little funk that seemed a bit off putting. It certainly improved after my expectations adjusted to it, however. It has those typical New glarus characteristics, wheras it feels very drinkable, with fairly subdued flavors. Nice Oktoberfest, but...

Bright, golden-orange color with medium white head. Clear barley malt aroma. Taste is light and crispy, but layered with a smooth malty quality. Flavors of malt, rye, and spices. Nice seasonal that isnt too filling.

12oz bottle from the Historic Casanova Liquors in Hudson, WI. Pours a crystal clear, deep golden colored body with a finger-width, frothy, white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma is some sweeter bread and caramels with a light, grainy toast. Some floral fruits and a light grass. Flavor is similar and on the thinner side. More sweet bread with some grainy toast and a lighter, sweet caramel. Flowery with some fruit and a light grassy hop. A pinch of butter, but not diacetyl. Finishes fairly sweet and bready with a light, floral fruity hoppiness thats somewhat dry. Medium length aftertaste following a light, crisp body and a moderately lively carbonation. Overall, I wasnt too impressed with this Oktoberfest. I was hoping for more out of New Glarus, but oh well. The grainy, bready sweetness and flowery flavor profile is nice and this is not a bad beer, but it was nothing special all-around.

12oz bottle poured golden brown with sizable head. Light and crisp with perfect fall spices. I like the beers balance  and it would serve as a great Autumn session beer. Probably my favorite Octoberfest Ive had to date.

12oz bottle
thanks to darklordlager for this beer
It pours a very nice orange/gold with a one finger white head. The flavor is malty, tasty & finishes slightly sweet. I think that this is a well-crafted oktoberfest

Bottle poured a clear amber with a lasting creamy amber head. Aromas of carmel, fruittiness and toasted malt. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, toasted malt and a hint of fruittiness with a smooth malty finish.
bottle at cranfest, clear burnt orange color with bright white foam, aroma is corn nuts and caramel, light smooth flavor of caramel and copper, finish is bitter and watery

On tap at their oktoberfest celebration at the brewery.  There is a very faint aroma of carmel.  Appearance is light amber color with a light density.  Low head amount.  Taste is of carmel and toasted notes.  Balanced malt and hops.  Aftertaste is crisp and refreshing.  More hops then an oktoberfest should have, but overall decent.  Not the best oktoberfest, but then again not the worst either.  Cool logo and I love the name...

Poured from 12 oz bottle, picked this up while visiting the New Glarus Brewery, enjoyed after running 10 miles in preparation for a marathon.  This is a fantastic Oktoberfest beer!  Aroma rich in caramel malt and lager yeast, very balanced in aroma which is unusual for the style from what Ive tried.  Appearance is a clear gold/amber with a decent head.  Taste is somewhat grassy, rather light, with a complex malt backing.  Very smooth, it was gone before I knew it!  Would drink again.

12 oz. Clear golden-amber with a lasting disc of bubbles. Faint nose of caramel, earthy leaf, and dry grass. Flavor is fresh caramel, toasted nut shell, dry grass, light tart fruit, wood, and earthy spice. Near-medium body is a bit tingly, malty but well-balanced, and smoothly carbonated.

12oz bottle.  Okay, not at all what I was expecting, but this is NG, so go figure.  Enjoying this while on the chat with some RBians, nice feature.  Pours a clear viscous looking clear orange golden with maybe a touch of red, frothy sudsy thin white head.  Strangely sweet and grassy aroma, the malt profile seems way more in depth than just munich malt, some munich malt rich caramel sweetness, but also like a white wine tanginess.  Flavor follows, bit of apple, very light caramel sweetness, some hop bitterness, more spicy than anything, tangy with metallic bitterness.  Medium/light bodied, spread-out sizzling carbonation, okay.
Poured from 12oz bottle, has a clear amber/golden color with nice white head, aroma is very sweet with malt and the flavor has a nice kick of spices with the malg, very smooth and delicious.

Appearance: - Light amber color with tons of thick frothy head

Aroma: grain - honey - that wonderful scent you catch when your outside at an oktoberfest, a little bit slosh buzzed - its cool weather, the german polka starts and you take a swig and while your nose is in your cup it catches a sweet whiff of none other than the smell that you can come to associate only with this time of year, the good company, and being buzzed in October. 

Taste: grain, honey, hint of jasmine - smooth, hint of orange. 

Palate: light - smooth

Overall: I highly recommend as a lighter octoberfest - this aint the beer you have to commit thirty-forty minutes to drink. If you want to sample some other beers after - this beer wont stand in the way - its simple, to the point, yet savory all rolled into one. I highly recommend. Thanks to a friend from WI - I was able to savor a few of these while in Cincinnati.
Hey, not bad at all. Very cool logo, great name. A perfect taste for making yourself comfortable. Thatll do.

Pours up a medium golden brown with a fine foamy head.  It smells of a nice meaty beer.  Taste is a tiny bit nutty, but overall quite good, with perhaps a hint of caramel.  The taste is not to strong, and its a good solid beer.
Pours a dark gold color. The nose is big of a sort of crisp malt tone. A lot of corn flavor develops in the taste. I wasnt wowed by the beer, but it did leave a pleaseat finish.

(12oz bottle thanks to bhops) Light golden color with oily bubbles on top. Nose of caramel, butter and corn. Taste of cereal grains, corn, garbage with a watery finish that reminds of old grains. Not a favorite style of mine, and this one isnt particularly good.
Thanks to Bhops for this one.  A classic Oktoberfest.  Nice, nice maltiness with hints of spice.  If I were living in Wisconsin, I would drink this all fall long!

12 oz. bottle from a friend in Madison, Wisconsin- Im not sure where she got it from.  Pours a nice clear brown-amber color with a small off-white. head.  Aroma of nuts, biscuits, caramel malts, floral hops, and spices.  Flavor gets a littel better, with nots of nuts, caramel mals, biscuit, spice, floral hops, and smoked wood.  Light-medium bodied, with average carbonation and a malty mouthfeel.  Pretty good beer, but I think I had this one a little past its prime.
Bottle thanks to bhops. Pours with a small white head with a clear golden body. Bread, caramel, toast, buttery. Buttery, fruity, caramel, toasted grain. Creamy carb.

12 ounce bottle poured into a pint glass. Clear amber color with a fluffy beige head. Aroma is bready with a nice tanginess, at times orangey. Crisp toasted bread, earthy bread crust, a little caramel and a hint of orange marmalade. Finishes very crisp but is a little on the thin, watery side. Cant fault any of the flavors though, another well constructed NG beer.

12 oz bottle, tasted in December 2009. Gold colour. Slightly bready aroma. More of the same on the palate. Some berry fruit. Not really that much going on here. Pleasant enough but this is a New Glarus beer that I cant get too excited about.
Bottle. Clear gold amber pour. Very malty aroma and flavor. Als some caramel on taste. Decent, not awesome.

12oz traded bottle after Mount Charleston snowshoe trip. Pours a clear copper colour with a disappearing off-white head. Caramel, cinnamon, biscuit and tons of malt in the aroma. Relatively simple flavour heavy on the malt and a little spice.
Bottle. Malty, caramelly, lightly toasty, lightly fruity, sweet. As expected.

Bottle thanks to FlssmrBrewAlum.  Pours a clear orange with a small white head.  Aroma of stale, grainy malt.  Flavor of sweet light malts and a grainy, crackery finish.  Some excess sweetness in the aftertaste.  On the bland side but ok overall for an oktoberfest.  
6/4/6/3/12 [3.1/5]

Bottle from a trade with FlssmrBrewAlum. Pours amber color with off white head. Caramel malt aroma. Caramel and toasted malt flavors. Moderately sweet. Medium body with soft carbonation. a decent Octoberfest. Thanks Adam.

12oz bottle from FlssmrBrewAlum.

Pours a spectacularly clear amber with a big creamy off-white head that shows excellent retention and lacing that clings to the side of the glass.

The aroma has a nice toasted caramel malt character with hints of sugar and definitely some barley.  The hops are there as well, some lightly spicy German-style hop aromas.

The taste is sweet, light malts with some toasted bread and spicy hops, especially in the finish.  Its extremely smooth and creamy for the style with the carbonation not getting in the way of the feel.  Overall, an excellent Oktoberfest.

Slight amber touch to a clear golden beer, wispy smallish head. Aroma is somewhat fruity, some sweetness and biscuit/dough/grain. I am not a fan of Octoberfests, but this isnt too bad. Malty without being overly sweet, very drinkable. There is a slight spice presence, no real hop presence, and a unique honeylike flavor at the finish, not bad.

A Mes rate. Bottle at home.A clean amber gold colour with a faint white rim. Pleasant aroma. Nice biscuity malt, decent grassy hops and some faint rice paper. In the mouth, its a fairly run of the mill Oktoberfest style beer. Clean and drinkable, faint cardboard, drinks like an English BCA that has not been bottled particularly well. Uneventful but ok.

Pours a rich orange yellow with a short and quickly dissipating head. The nose is fruity with a quick malt sweetness. Mouthfeel is surprisingly smooth and creamy and I might be drinking this beer a little cold, so it is doubly surprising that it retains that character. I am having trouble identifying the herb/spice flavors in the middle of this one, and will suddenly realize what it is as soon as I post the rating. This is a nice beer in a style that I dont usually care much for and yet another strong effort from a New Glarus.

12 oz bottle.  Clear pink orange with a smooth white coating.  Nose is dough and cinnamon toast.  Medium body with a sharp tang.  Taste is caramel and lemon, light roast.  Dry finish with some sweet tobacco.

translucent gold with orange hint. aroma is tantalizing bready malt with hint of citrus. flavor is wonderful balance of fresh breads and near lemony tang. palate is surprisingly towards the soft end of the spectrum, moreso then the body would predict.

Orange/amber pour.  Not much head.  Aroma is full of fruity and caramel malt with some sweet toasted malt as well.  Flavor is a mix of caramel, fruit, and a itty bitty bit of hops.  Unique beer.  Pretty good.

Solid oktoberfest bier here. Toasted malts on the nose, some nutty notes and light sweet caramel. Pours golden amber with a thin head, bright and nice looking. Toasted malts in the flavor, a little bread, caramel, and nuts. Solid crispness in the finish. Well done.

If I had to describe this octoberfest in one word, it would be toasty... Big toasty aroma, some toasted nutty flavor, with a thin to medium mouthfeel. Not my favorite octoberfest, but its not bad either.

Bottle from allendodd. Thanks for this one. Pours a very light amber with a large, frothy off-white head. Aroma is fresh fruit and caramel. Rather light in body with frothy carbonation. Flavor is caramel and some sort of light fruit. Finishes mildly fruity and lightly caramel. Not real flavorful, but nice to drink.

Bottle. Pours a coppery brown color with a small off white/tannish head.  Aroma has a sweet malty grain, barley, apple and grass.  Flavor is mostly caramel and grain with secondary hints of spices and a touch of orange peel.

From a 12oz. bottle poured into a Lager glass at 40°.  Color is a deep gold with light carbonation and a small head.  Aroma is sweet with malt and caramel.  Starting with a medium body it goes down with a rich feel.  Finish is a sweet candy corn malt taste backed with a hop spice and mellow bitterness.  After taste lets the malt come back out for just a moment then leaves you with a smooth feel.  Overall its a well done brew just not a style I really like.

Bottle via trade thanks to badbeer on BA.  Pours a clear light amber color with a foamy one-finger white head.  Aroma is caramel, grain, earth, and mild toast.  Flavor is pretty well-balanced, but not amazing, with sweet caramel malt, mild roast, earth, toffee, and some hop bitterness.  Palate is smooth and crisp, and body is medium-light.  This is nice for the style, but nothing to write home about overall.

Bottle.  Pours a crystal clear amber-orange with a soapy white heat. Aromas of caramel and grain, some earthy goodness. Flavors of caramel and toast with a grainy finish. Nice example of the style from NG!

Bottle thanks to MrPickles.  
Light aroma and flavor, but nothing offensive.  Body is a little thin and watery though.  An average beer, but not a great Oktoberfest. I didnt pick up on any of the "toasty" flavors several others have mentioned.  Overall, light, but drinkable.

A good sized sample courtesy of Clint at the South Loop taproom (Chicago, IL). Pours a very nice caramel orange amber, a light haze, decent offwhite head that laces fairly well, sticks around a suitable amount. Aromas are a good crisp graininess, caramel sweetness, toffee, toast, a touch of spice, and a feeling of fall. Initial is a bit roasty and toasty, breaking free to caramel and toffee sweetness to balance, light bitterness, nothing too crazy on the spice. A good nose, a good sessionable fall lager that provides pretty solid flavors and sessionability. Perhaps a little typical for the style, but a solid beer Id drink again soon. Cheers.

Bottle thanks to Bigmmartin.  Pours an amber color with red hues when held up to the light.  Aroma is caramelized malts.  Notes of some autumn spices come out as well.  On the palate, it is much lighter than I expected.  The flavor brings out the sweet malts and leaves an aftertaste of caramel.  Not a favorite, kinda let me down.
Light amber pour with an off-white head. Malt aroma, caramel. Taste is caramel, crisp flavor. The maltiness lingers around for awhile.
A fine sample of a marzen.  Perfect clear amber colored body with a small off white head.  A mix of caramel a sweet malts.  Some apple on the flavor also.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2014 Pours deep red/amber with pumkin and spice aroma. Small off white head. Good mouthfeel. pumpkin, bread, malty and spice. Cloves in particular. Chewy bread malts. Clean, smooth, and roasty. really great

(bottle) Pours a deep reddish copper with a thin white head that leaves good lacing.  Huge aroma of barley, caramel, musty basement, roasted peanuts, and a light undertone of candied apple, but this is quite a barley bomb.  The taste follows the same as the aroma, sans candied apple, with some salt and a really pleasant roasted barley and fresh fried doughnut finish.  Mouthfeel is medium and carbonation is spot on.  This is extremely drinkable, but Im not surprised in the least.  Yet another solid showing from NG.

Bottle - Picked it up nice and fresh this year. Pours clear amber with a small white head. Smells clean, with barley, a little sweet malt, and some grassy hops. Taste is mild malt and barley, with some biscuity flavors. Just a little grassy hops on the finish. Its syrupy and medium-bodied. Tastes a lot like the Unplugged Bohemian Lager, but I usually like a little more sweet malt in an Oktoberfest. Still, a fine beer.

12oz bottle 9/13/09 (New Glarus Brewing)-Pours a light amber with a small scattered white covering. Aroma of malt, sweetness, caramel, and candy. Taste of the same with a big amount of maltiness and sweetness. This medium bodied brew is very flavorful and well balanced. I am not a fan of this style but this is pretty tasty stuff.
Fruity/sweet aroma.  Good malty character with good balance.  Almost some estery undertones.  One of my favorite Wisconsin Oktoberfests.

Amber beer with a thin white head.  The aroma is loaded with soft maltiness.  Lightly swet and toasty with a bit of Munich malt sweetness.  Excelent cleanliness with a crisp fresh breadiness.  Softly sweet and a  little toasty.  A touch of light herbal character.  Sweet and balanced and fairly toasty.  Nice brew.

12 ounce- copper orange- excellent clarity.  Sticky off white head.  Nose- grassy hops, candied fruit. Taste- bready biscuit malts, higher than expected hoping giving a dry finish. Very drinkable.  Carbonation level is good.  Well crafted brew.

12oz Bottle - Trade - JJClark
Aroma: Sweet malty Marzen.  Some big Carmel riffs. 
Appearance: Amber in color, clear with a thin head.  
Flavor: Big malt flavor with light hops.  This was an Okotberfest for sure. .  
Palate: Dry finish, with a Good Mouthfeel.  
Overall: A very nice Marzen.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2009 12 oz bottle thanks to JJclark pours a amber and clear with small head aromas of caramel malts and hops flavor is a sweet malted barley and hops also not the best marzen Ive had but a very worthy brew

12 oz. bottle (2008) in a lager glass- thanks jbean! Rocky, soap-sud head w/ decent retention leaving some low fungal tops. Clear red-amber color. Fruity malt aroma w/ hints of a delicate, underlying spicy hops. Very clean flavor, malty and w/ a surprisingly pronounced hops profile. True to style and extremely refreshing. Palate seems a little thin initially, ending w/ a Pilsner-ish flourish at the end.

12oz bottle.  Clear amber pour with a big off-white head.  Sweet and malty aroma with some yeast.  Caramel malt flavor backed up by some lager yeast.  Not bad by any means, but kinda boring.  I will say this, it has that drinkability thing that all the kids are going nuts for these days.

Bottle from Noncaloric. Not too much head on the pumpkin-orange pour. Very toasty and nutty aroma, a touch of spice, quite seasonal and refreshing, while also warming. Perfect crunchy-sweet barley flavor, notes of pumpkin and fall leaves and other such lovely autumn flavors. A fine brown sugar sweetness  really does wonders for this beer. A perfect example of an Oktoberfest, one of the best Ive had.

Caramel malt and wheat grass aromas with a bit of citrus frutiness.  Reddish orange clear body with off white bubbly head. Flavor is somewhat fruity with a bitter woody finish. A slight bit of saltiness, some toffee and perhaps a little coffee. Palate is medium with a bitter mild, rye bread like duration.  Pretty good.
Interesting marzen. A little stonger than you normally taste with this style. Not a great flavor profile, but its drinkable and tasty. Good brew.
Bottle thanks to Skyview.  Pours a light copper orange with a finger of lightly off white foam.  Sweet caramel aroma.  Taste is mildly peppery, spicy, caramel, toffee, a bit nutty.  Average Marzen.

Bottle. Clear copper pour with a off-white, mostly diminishing head. Grainy, vegetal aroma with some metallic notes along with hints of bread. The flavor is lightly to moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly sweet and lightly bitter. Tastes of grass with some caramel notes along with a hint of canned corn juice. Medium body with watery texture that turns sticky in the finish. Moderate carbonation.
Bottle poured to glass.  Copper, brown brew.  Aroma of heavy roasted grains in the aroma and soft bitters behind.  Buiscuity malt flavro with floral hops after taster.  The mouth feel is a bit thin.

Bottle:  Poured a bright, clear copper color with a creamy beige head.  Nice marzen aroma is a balanced malty, sweet, bready, and of light florals.  Tastes light florals up front into sweet malts, some bready notes, and lingering bitters in the tail.  A little dry, just light hints of grass.  Still, quite nice.  Thanks nimbleprop.
Trade with noncaloric. Very light head on delicate amber. Nut and roasted malt scent. Delicate and enjoyable bready nut flavour.
Bottle. Pours an orangish-red with a fair amount of head; quite carbonated. Spices are definitely present in the aftertaste. Has some nice lacing.
Light orange color, with a diminishing head and minimal lacing. Spiced finish, some cinnamon. A lot of malt. High drinkability.
12 ounce bottle. Pours a clear amber with a small head. Average lacing. Aroma is toasted malts, caramel and cinnamon. Taste is sweet roasted malts with cinnamon and slight graininess. Medium bodied.

12oz Bottle. Aroma glows with a bevy of slowly cooked whole grains, light fruity yeast character and snappy distant hop essence. Rich and inviting. Pours a very, very clear ochre-orange, with a soft, soapy foam lying above. Flavor develops some slightly tangy deeper malt character while defining a crisp, cool edge to the fruity Munich profile. Good levels of Munich here. Bright, refreshing and classic. This is quintessential German-American brewing. Nothing wildly flavored, just clean, fresh bright malty beer. A true Marzen.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2009 Clear red color, lots of carbonation. Frothy head. Roasty aroma. Woody. Initially slightly sweet, then tangy and sour in finish. Light body. Thin texture. Long finish. Overall impression: decent beer, but not as good as their fat squirrel.

12oz bottle.  Filtered amber brown color with a satisfactory head.  Brewery fresh aroma, delightful.  Malty body is crisply balanced with the minimal to-style hopping.  This is an awesome Oktoberfest, with subtle fruity notes shining through in the aftertaste.  Malty all the way, very well done.

This smells like beer, not in a stereotypical way, it smells like what it smells like inside a brewery, beautiful caramel malt aromas, followed by sweet and very mild floral and noble hop notes. The beer pours with a nice white head that leaves a pretty thick ring around the edge of the glass, and plenty of lace on the sides. The colour is a reddish orange and just looks gorgeous in a dim lit room. Oh my, this tastes better than I remember! There is a slight sticky sweetness that almost overwhelms the flavors, but works as a good canvas for noble earthy hops, French bread, and a cherry like fruitiness. The palate here is so well rounded silky on the top sharp on the sides, really not much happening going down.

Pours a true copper color with a robust whitish head that settles quickly...solid levels of lacing.  Aroma is all sweet malts and toasted nuts..nothing amazing, but pleasant.  Flavor is slightly more robust than the average Marzen...it is very sweet, full of roasted malt flavors, but is not as thin as I feel most oktoberfests are, but it remains highly drinkable.  Slight hints of spice keep this one interesting as well.  Good offering from NG, if not overwhelming in any category.
Pours copper with a thin white head.  Smells of sweet malt, some nutty hints, toasty.  Tastes of sweet malt with a decent peppery splash on the finish.

Pretty nose that almost goes as deep as some cheap single malts scotches.  However, smells very authentic and earthy--not that scotches don’t, but this smells very unique. Perhaps I feel this way because I haven’t had an un-pasteurized beer in a while and I have been drinking alot of Macallan lately.  Anyway, Palate is fruity (?) mildly hoppy, creamy, and finishes pleasant but a little fluffy in a breadlike kind of way (if that makes any sense).  Overall, OK but not one to hang your hat on.

Pours a beatiful clear amber topped by a small light tan head. Nose is faint malt and caramel. Mouthfeel is very creamy and pleasant. Taste is malt with a kick of hops to dry the finish. Nice beer but not the best of New Glarus’ stable. Pairs well with ham and cheese/pretzels.
Rich, coppery color. Pleasant malty/hoppy flavor. This is an outstanding Oktoberfest/ marzen.

12oz. bottle:  This one pours a very clear copper color.  There was a very small white head on it that went away almost immediately.  The aroma is caramel malt, and some slightly spicy hops.  It has a very clean and crisp taste.  Caramel malts with some spiciness.  It is a very well executed Oktoberfest.

I don’t think you can take much artistic license with an Oktoberfest, and this one doesn’t...it sticks with a formula and delivers a clean, crisp beer that makes me think of it as what an Oktoberfest should be. It is a rich copper color, has nice pilsner-like head, and an aroma that malty and light without being grainy or cerealy or overly malt-ball sweet. Flavor is crisp and malty, with a nice structure and noticeable hoppiness. Mouthfeel is quite clean with just a touch of metallic tang. It is really quite nice.

I would recommend this beer. Best Oktoberfest I’ve had in recent memory. I bought this bottle at Three Cellars in Franklin, WI.

Pours dark reddish copper with thin tan head that fades fast. Aroma of caramel and some roast malts, slight citrus hops. Flavor has a bit more hops than I am used to in an octoberfest and its really quite enjoyable. Starts off with roast malt, lime citrus hops, and an earth mustiness that adds alot of charater. FInish is some sweetbread malts and bitter hops. Overall a great marzen.

Pours an amber hue with a one-fingered, tan head.  Has a nice flavor of roasted malts, caramel  and a crisp hoppy finish.  This might be the best Oktoberfest I’d had.  A nicely balanced brew that is very easy to drink.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a nice amber color with golden highlights and an off white head that has nice lacing.  Aroma is of faint caramel maltiness.  Flavor is a nice "sharp" caramel malt flavor with a slight hop bitterness at the end.  Very smooth and balanced beer.  It is a good Oktoberfest but I was hoping for a little more.

Pour is clear orange/golden with a fluffy off white head.  Aroma is lightly malty with a medium clean hop aroma.  Flavor is damn smooth of very lightly roasted barley, light spice, light hop, and a somewhat sweet finish.  Real smooth creamy brew.  Extremely easy drink.  Would drink again.
UPDATED: OCT 21, 2008 Crushed with Jakebra.  Very nice, intense and malty aroma is misleading because theres not much flavor here.  Still, its okay for a Oktoberfest.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2008 Copper/orange color with a creamy tan head. A very nicely balanced brew. Aroma is sweet and malty yet has a nice hoppy spice to it. Has a rich malty mouth feel with a bite. The bottle says they use "the worlds most expensive hops." I dont know about all of that but they are good and it shows
Oktoberfest tasting Three Cellars Milwaukee.  One of the better New Glarus Brews.  Some richness from barley and a nice amber color.
12oz, bottle, aroma is very malty and roasty, nothing too good here, pretty boring, but again its easy to drink and enjoyable.

Pours orange with a nice head. Aroma is malty, toasty, touches of cider. Great balanced flavor, the leafy hops and the sweet malt complement each other well making it extremely drinkable. Strong, full bodied, and easily my favorite example of the style.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2009 Bottle, pilsner glass.  Malty aromas, a touch on the toasty side.  Pours a very clear orange-gold.  A fingers worth of off-white head dissipates, but a ring remains, maintained by effervescence.  Flavor profile is mostly malty, fairly understated, pronouncedly worty.  Hints of orange, vanilla, oatmeal.  Just a touch of bitterness and tang on the finish.  Mild carbonation on the palate, clean drinking.

2007 Version

Pours a beautiful, crystal clear, amber color. Head retains well. Smell is slightly floral, biscuity, and a hint of a lager-like smell (light DMS?). Pretty balanced between the malt and the hops; seems to have a higher level of hop flavor and bitterness. I seem to remember a rich smell of fresh malt, similar to that at the brewery or when I’m homebrewing, this doesn’t seem to have it as much. Carbonation is medium and it’s medium bodied; sits pretty good on the tongue. Pretty damn good beer, better than my numbers may reflect, but doesn’t seem to have the huge malty aroma jumping out at me like the previous batch.

bottles by way  of the bockyhorseys... clear coppery brown color with a small off white/tannish head. smells like apple pie spices... apples, golden raisins, sweet malty grain, barley, vegetable stock, earthy and a little grass. the palate is a touch sweet but finishes up dry. the flavor is mostly caramel and grain with secondary hints of spices and orange peel. tart dry finish is slightly bitter. medium body gets quite creamy as it’s sloshed around.

in bottle. light amber in color. the thin white head dies quickly. malty toasted aroma with a bit of aldehyde. big nuttiness to the flavor, a mild tartness to the finish. this has a heavier malt palate than most oktoberfest beers. one could not pound these at a festival.

Hazy orange with a  medium slowly dissipating beige head.  Aroma of caramel, toffee and bread.  Taste of caramel, toffee, mild sugar and other sweet malts.  Creamy and mostly malted, also a bit thin.  An okay marzen.
Pours a copper body with a small head. slighty nutty character and ripe fruit in the aromas alogn with apple pie and oak. mouthfeel is very full with a heavy well balanced taste and slightly peppery.

5-7-08 bottle shared with lb4lb thanks to Iowaherkeye 
Semi clear amber orange with no lasting head.  Very subtle smell of malt and metal.  Flavor is super bland with only a hint of pumpkin spice behind a very obvious malty metal flavor.  It just tastes old and past its prime.

Bottle:  Pours a very beautiful orange that just reminds me of fall leaves.  Aroma is toasted caramel malts and some light spice, reminiscent of pumpkin pie spice.  Flavor is also toasted malts, caramel undertone, doughy, and although I can still smell spices when I drink it, they dont translate to the palate.  I, too, think I waited a little too long on this one and that it would be great fresh.
user_location: I F&ckin hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text: Pours a copper color with a white head.  Aroma is toasty, pear, and caramel.  Flavor is malty, toasty, pear, and sweet caramel finish.

Bottle courtesy of Iowaherkeye.  Thanks!
Think I waited to long on this beer.  Pours a bright clear reddish orange malt with a small beige head.  Smell is sticky, stale, gooey malt with band aid qualities and metal.  Probably not as it was intended.  Unappealing malt flavor and metal as well.

Bottle from bockyhorsey. Amber shaded straw, decent sudsy heat and lacing. Aroma of pils malts, grassy and bready notes. Flavor was stark pilsner-like, although toasted elements and bread were also present. The mouthfeel was full bodied, malty-hardy, balancing carbonation. Thanks, Bill!
A nice amber color with a small white head.  Slight aroma of hops and straw malt.  Flavor is sweet malt and light hops.  Medium body with a nice clean finish.  Good beer for the style.

Appearance: hazy copper, wispy off white head, streaks of drippy lace
Aroma: sweet bready malt aroma with a nice caramel sweetness and a light earthyness
Flavor: rich sweet malt flavor, lots of sourdough bread character, light balancing earthyness
Overall: light a big bite of fresh sourdough bready covered in honey butter
