Bottle. Copper color, amber color with a thin white head. Strong taste and aroma of crystal malts. A bit sweeter than I expected. Bitter finish. Pretty average beer if you ask me. Not extraordinary but not bad.

Pours a brilliant clearish orange color, white head that fades quickly to nothing, no lace. Smells malty. Tastes malty sweet with just a hint of brown sugar. Almost dry tasting. This is the best tasting Oktoberfest Ive ever had.
Nice, full mouthfeel. Nice vibrant carbonation. Very good beer. Not one of those Oktoberfests that is so sweet you can only drink one.

Pours a clear golden orange color with a small, foamy white head.  The foam settles to a wspy film, leaving random spots of lacing behind.  The aroma is malty, with toasty caramel and cereal grains showing behind a veil of fruity esters and nutty notes.  The flavor follows suit, with toasty almonds and light floral hops blending well with caramel malts and dry roasted grains.  The medium-full, slightly sugary mouthfeel is smooth and pleasing, finishing short, sweet, and malty.  Overall, pretty solid for the style.

(Bottle) Pours a light amber color with a small white head. Malty aroma includes cereal grains and lots of sweet toffee. Taste is rather sweet, with a good amount of caramel, nut, and biscuit. Lively carbonation, and a better than expected mouthfeel. Extremely drinkable, and very good overall.
pours clear amber color thin white head,light carmel malt nose,nice lite spice malt,very light hop finish...goood october beer..

12-oz bottle received via SS 07, holdenn.  Pours clear amber with a spare, fizzy, white head, mostly diminishing with fair lacing.  Aroma is average malt (grain, cereal, meal), light hops (grass), average yeast (sweat, earth) with notes of cooked corn.  Light bodied, oily texture, soft carbonation, and a chalky finish.  Average duration, light sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.
Clear amber color with small head. Malty light caramel aroma. The taste was the same with lite spice and nice light roasted character. Thanks, Mark.

Courtesy of Styles
Bottle:  The aroma is grainy with some caramel, fruit, and grass.  It pours a transparent amber with a small white head.    The flavor starts with caramel and fruit that turns to an herbal grassy bitterness in the finish.  Medium-bodied with mild carbonation.

12oz bottle from Brigadier.  Aroma:  Rich maltiness with a strong toast.  Light brown sugar and citrus.  Some light herbal hop notes as it warms.  Appearance:  Deep orange in color and clear.  Light beige head was full and foamy with good retention.  Nice lacing.  Flavor:  Medium sweet maltiness with notes of toasted nuts and brown sugar.  Some light herbal and citrus notes mid taste.  Bitterness was just enough to do its job.  Finishes dry.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Medium carbonation.  Overall:  A pleasant marzen.  A good drinker with some good flavor.
UPDATED: DEC 2, 2007 This is a smooth beer that tastes like a German and should be enjoyed a little towards room temperatr to get all of the flavor.  Good finish.

12oz bottle courtesy of mother in law.  Spicey bitter aroma. Orange body with off white head disipated quickly. Flvor was just ordinary nothing special your spicey, bitter and sweet malt. Alright but no ahh factor here.

Bottle from trade with shigadeyo. Poured clear dark copper color with a large frothy off-white head that was mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate toasted sweet malt aroma. Medium body. Medium balanced flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. The beer goes well with a spicy food.

12 oz bottle. Right off the bat I like the depth of this beer. Nice amber color, decent head. Medium bodied and smooth. Big soft malts dominate the palate, warm sugar and just a bit of bittering hop at the end. Have to say this is up there with the better Oktoberfest beers.

12oz bottle, courtesy of KingPinIPA.  Thanks, Mike!  Pours a bright, clear leafy orange color; fluffy off-white head fading to a thin perimeter of bubbles.  Chewy, raw candy sugar and light citrus in the aroma; basic sweet malts.  Surprisingly generous in the mouthfeel: plenty of sticky candy sugar and dried fruit; spritzy, sharp citrus on the front of the tongue, but slightly metallic (well, not metallic, but still sharp) along the edges; the mild acidity makes this malt-forward beer quite drinkable, but unremarkable otherwise (and the level of complexity of the malts doesnt approach something like Ayinger).  Medium, candy sugar and dried fruit finish; a bit cloying, with oranges.
12 ounce bottle. English Pint. Amber with a thin head. Aroma - malt and fruit. Taste was dominated by roast malt and carmale with a nice balance of spice and earthy hops. Very nice.

10/20/2007:  New Glarus Staghorn Octoberfest Beer is a wonderful, bright orange/pale amber color that is quite clear.  There is a moderate level of carbonation and a diminishing beige/ivory head.  The aroma has some sweet pale malt along with a nicely noticeable level of sugary caramel.  The flavor is strong and lightly roasted with a smooth caramel quality and a hint of nuts (pecan?) and freshly baked bread or something.  The finish is nicely mild with some lingering sweetness along with a traces of a delicate floral hoppiness and a weak coffee-like flavor.  The mouthfeel clean and smooth with a medium to medium-full body.  I personally think that this is a really good Octoberfest and probably one of the best Ive had this season.  This is an Octoberfest brew that I could actually enjoy several bottles of in one sitting - maybe even a full six pack and then some!
12 fl. oz. bottle from New Glarus Brewing Company in New Glarus, Wisconsin.  Rating #138 for this beer.

12 oz bottle from iowaherkeye - thanks Joey! Clear amber pour with an off white head. Well carbonated. Nutty malt nose, flavor mimics the nose. Clean, mildly bitter earthy finish. Solid, but one dimensional.
Bright autumn orange in color.  Peach aroma.  Tingling mouthfeel, sweet malt, and oranges?

Slight toasted aroma, with a bit of nuts, and a touch of lager aroma.  Pours a clear amber with just a dusting of head.  Not much flavorwise here, just a touch of sweet malts and a dash of carbonation.  Drinkable, but not remarkable.
Too much roasted malt in here.  tastes like fat squirrel, a lot.  not very sweet.  a poor attempt at a marzen/octoberfest.  it is was marketed as else i would enjoy it more, not what i expected.

Not a huge fan of the Oktoberfests anyway. This was fairly unremarkable. Tasted fine but was just really average. I have come to expect quite a bit from New Glarus and this one really didnt impress me in anyway.
Light but well done and balanced. One of the better Marzen Octoberfests Ive tried. Highly drinkable.

Bottle.  Pours copper with a thin light tan head.  Faint aroma of wheat and some spices.  Taste of caramel, spice, nuts and some earthiness.  Thin and watery.  Im not a fan of this style.  This one doesnt stand out, but is easy to drink.
Bottle. Pours a hazy copper color with a medium off white head. Aroma of nuts roasted malts, and caramel. Tastes of nuts, yeast , and hops.  Has a slight caramel flavor in the bitter finish.

A huge creamy head tops the pale orange/copper body.  The aroma has clean toasted malt with a touch of caramel sweetness.  Nice lively carbonation.  It has a lightly toasted bread flavor with some malty sweetness and a very light earthy bitterness to balance it out.  Pretty decent.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Cellars, Franklin, WI<font size=-1>

Bottle, big thanks to Iowaherkeye! Pours a crystalline copper with a small fluffy head. I get sticky caramel, green apples, leaves, and a bit of vegetation in the nose. After taking a sip, I have to say I was expecting a bit more hops. I wasnt thinking anything crazy, but this one seems to be focused more on the malty qualities and is on the sweeter side, sporting some candied attributes.  It has a faint hint at biscuits with a barely tart finish.  All right for an Oktoberfest, I suppose. I just cant get into the style.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of Bockyhorsey - Pours a clear amber color with a one finger thick off white head.  Aroma is light bread and herbal hops.  Flavor is light toasted malt.  Palate is slightly bitter.  Medium body.  A nice beer.  Thanks Bill.

A nice Oktoberfest Marzen that really shines with traditioal flavor.  Full malty taste with a hint of biscuit/graininess.  I enjoy drinking this one each year.  Not my absolute favorite, but still a winner in my opinion.  Clear as a bell red/amber with a long lasting head.  The caramel aspect really shines through with this beer.  Hops are present, yet not in the fore front.

Medium clean copper with a small off white head. Fair carbonation. Aroma and flavor is mild sweet malts, caramel, light spice and tart nuttiness. Pretty much a basic Oktoberfest which is not a bad thing. Very solid overall.

Thanks to drewberme for the bonus.  Pours a bright coppery amber with an initial foamy head, but fades over time to nothing.  Aroma is lightly toasted malts, sweet, herbal and spicy hops with a touch of white wine.  Light toasted malts, vienna, and a touch of sharp crystal malt sweetness.  Body is a bit on the weakside, but otherwise this is a pretty solid o-fest.

Pours a dark prestine amber.  Aroma is of caramel and roasted malts.  Taste has a hint of caramel at first, then some bittnerness, and followed by the roasted malts.  A bit too rich for me, but still good.

12 oz bottle bought in WI at some liquor store ill put in here when i remember or when andrew bms me (whatever comes first)  Pours a clear orange read with a white head that quickly fades to a ring.  Nose isnt too much to speak of.  Toasted malts, marzen, carmel, and a touch of spice.  Marzen carmelled flavors.  Nutty and toasted with a finish that slightly bitter cloying and dirty.  Hmm, Im not usually a fan of this style, so hey maybe its me.

12oz, no date--though I know its been bottled within the last month.  Clear orange with hints of brown with a 1/2 finger off-white head.  Aroma of nuts, toasted malts, caramel, and only a hint of floral hops.  Flavor was fairly sweet--as most Oktoberfests are--and I couldnt really pick up on any hops.  Lots of caramel in the flavor along with some light toasted nuts and malts.  Very low bitterness.  Moderate creamy carbonation with a medium body.  A very well-made Oktoberfest.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Thanks to Skyview for sharing.  Light malt nose.  Faint head.  Orange color.  Pretty standard lightly roasted caramel malt aroma and body.  d
This is an excellent oktoberfest.  Flavor is more complex than most, and I get some wheat in addition to caramel malt and light spices.  Dark orange color.  Top of its style.

Aroma was toasty malt, a touch of apple,and just a little zing of hop,that being said you really had to troll your nose to pick up up any of this,taste was the slightly sweet flavor of German yeast,had a little bit of bitterness after the third sip, refreshing, a nice session brew,but nothing like you get at the German Beer Hall in Milwaukee
Amber color.  Smell of malt, bread, caramel, sugar and minor spice.  Taste of caramel, malt, spice, bread, nuts and minor hops.  Refreshing and crisp.

Picked up a six-pack from Bob McFarlands Liquors in McFarland, Wisocnsin. Pours a clear old copper penny amber brew with a fast dissolving off-white head that leaves behind a ring and film top. Aroma of caramel malt, some flowery hops and a touch of sweet apple and honey. Taste is medium bodied, plenty of carbonation with flavors of sweetened caramel, roasted nuts, some spiced apple and a touch of honey. Finish is semi-sweet with a more caramel malt aftertaste than bitterness. Good and bready malty oktoberfest style beer.
Pours a dark amber with a smallish head. Aroma of caramel with a bit of fruit and nuts and toastiness as well in there. Some earthiness comes through in the flavor. Solid beer.

12oz bottle. pours reddish copper with small white head. nose is bready, nuts, and grainy. not a big aroma. flavor is pretty bready, with some a nice hop flavor and sweet malty finish. watery mouth feel. decent. i like this more than my score indicates but hey the score is the score.

12 oz bottle
I knew this was coming out soon but it still caught me by surprise on a beer run.  I now have five more to enjoy for the next few months to tide me over until the new year.  The Organic Pale Ale (the winter release) sounds like it could be interesting but doesnt quite get my blood pumping.  This is one that has been around for a while and Im glad to see it back.  Its not the best Oktoberfest beer but it is certainly well made.
Aroma / Appearance - Lively carbonation percolates from the bottom of my sampler glass throughout the rusty brown body.  Malt and cherry extract are the key components of a relatively simple nose.  I wasnt expecting much from an Oktoberfest though.
Flavor / Palate - Nutty malts fade quickly into walnuts and then nothing.  The dry finish leaves one wanting more - I could have easily had two more over the rest of the evening.  It is perfect for a cool fall day sitting on a porch.  Easy to drink and affordable I think Dan Carey should keep this in the annual rotation.

This marzen pours a deep copper color from a 12oz bottle. Small sized quickly dissipating white foamy head. Aroma is fruity and caramel. A medium to full bodied marzen. The malts are caramel and fruity and not very sweet. The hops are spicy and earthy. Nice balance. The carbonation is fairly lively, but its a whole bunch of small bubbles. Nice Oktoberfest beer, lots of flavor in this one. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is crisp and dry. Aftertaste is slightly spicy and bitter.

Its beginning to be that time of year again...and this is one of the beers Ive looked forward to for Oktoberfest.  Nice orange color, lots of malty fruity flavor that meshes with the aroma, and a clean finish.  A very good Marzen.

Poured a rich amber with a quickly fading head.  Strong aroma of malt and spices.  Very powerful taste of dark malts and a few lingering spices.  Had a slight warming effect on the throat with a decent aftertaste.  Not a big fan of Oktoberfest beers, but this one was pretty good.

Thanks to thefatkid13 for this brewski.

Pour was, less then stellar. Pretty heavy pour yielded a color that looked like darkened apple juice, but no head at all. However, that is the only down side to this brew. I might need a another furley, just to re-puor it. :) The smell on this is solid, with spices and grains. Taste is very good, and easily put down. Thanks again kid.

Pours a very clear deep reddish copper, briefly topped by half an inch of off-white foam, then replaced by a very thin ring of foam and an even thinner layer of film. No lacing. Mild caramel and some sweet fruitiness in the aroma.

Very tasty beer - lots of toasted malt, some caramel, some grain, a hint of chocolate, and fruit. A mild hop presence in the finish provides good balance. Quite a bit of that sweet fruitiness remains in the aftertaste.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2007 12 oz bottle. Poured a clear medium orange color. Head was off white and reduced fairly quickly to a thin film. Not much lace was left behind. Aroma was of light brown sugar with a papery note. Fruity and slightly sweet with toasted nut and a bit of spicy black pepper accompanied by light malty caramel/molasses flavors. Decent beer, but a bit overrated.

12oz bottle. Poured a medium and slightly hazy copper color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of toasted malts, burnt, caramel, and some nuts. Tastes of caramel, toasted nuts, and lightly bready. Tastes started out nice but had a weak and thin finish.

Aroma of caramel and vienna malt, some biscuit, all-natural peanut butter.  Appears a crystal-clear copper color with no noticeable effervescence and with no head to speak of.  Flavor is malty, sweet, biscuity, with moderate spice in the finish.  Palate is thick and chew, yet somehow refreshing in the end. Overall, this is a pleasant brew, and one that is just a bit greater than the sum of its parts.
Sweet and tasty. Amber colored beer goes down smooth and is very satisfying. Maltly flavor put this one heads above most marzens I tasted. Not the best Ive had, but a solid effort.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2007 This is one of my favs for new glaur! This is what Oktober should taste like, not to dark, but dark enough, with a rich full body that goes down EZ duz it. The caramel taste makes me go like this! go like this! it makes ya go GO GO!!!

Pours amber with red highlights and an off-white head.  Aroma of malts, toffee and caramel with mild hop undertones.  Flavor follows aroma wonderfully and introduces a slight malty sweetness with a nice crisp light bitter hop finish.

I can honestly say that this is my favorite of the New Glarus bunch. Warm, malty flavor that finishes very nicely clean.  A nice compliment to those late fall barbecues or for sitting around the fire as its rich, almost caramel toffee  taste enlivens the senses.
Yay!  I love good Octoberfests.  Caramel, brown sugar, and pecans.  A light touch of herbs and spice from the hops.  Smooth, thick, rich, and non-sticky.  Excellent all-round.

Bottle via trade with DavidP.  Clearish amber-red body, thin off-white head.  Rich toasty, caramely, cerealy aroma with earthy hops notes.  The sweet caramels and cereals are cut by a nice, crisp bitterness and earthy hops finish.  Not heavy or cloying like many Oktoberfests.  New Glarus is one of the best brewers of session ales and lagers there is.

bottle from santa. amber light brown pour with a circle of ash for a head. grain nose with some honey straw and a touch of oxidation. maltball flavor with some carrot cake, newspaper and dust. grainy finish. some cashew and peanuts in the finish.

Poured a rich red-amber color w/ a short head, scant lacing and a mild fruity aroma with touch of hops and hint of alcohol.  Light bodied with a smooth malty flavor, some toastiness and slightly bitter in the finish. Just so-so, no date.
Medium amber with a small head.  Malty aroma wtih hints of toffee.  Malt and caramel flavor finished kinda weak.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a beautiful tawney color with a small white head that settled quickly.  Generous amounts of Munich malt in the nose imparting a nice toffee and caramel scent.  Flavor is rather unimpressive.  None of the caramel and toffee flavor expected with that nose.  A little bit of cardboard in the finish makes me wonder if this is maybe last years batch.  Medium bodied with soft carbonatioon.  Overall not a real great attempt at an Octoberfest.  Left me underwhelmed.
Pours to a medium head; amber color. Tastes of malt and a tinge of alcohol. Slightly sweet, too. This is a pretty good Octoberfeste beer.

clear amber/copper with a medium off white frothy head that is quickly discipating and leaving no lace. Nose is malty with barly and touch of alcohol. Taste is sweet with caramel and candy from back to front. Overall clan and crisp, thirst quenching.
Took the tour and then paid $3.50 for three samples...this was one of the choices. It was OK...would have liked to have a real glass to see how it started AND finished.

12 oz. bottle.  picked up as part of a mix-a-six over the weekend in Wis.  copper colored with a fast fading off-white head.  aroma of caramel malt, toffee and some spiced apples.  flavors are pretty much the same with a clean finish.  nice marzen.
Pours out a clear copper with a small off-white head.  Malty and vinous to the nose.  Sweet caramel.  All carries over to the flavor.  Medium bodied, light carbonation.  Quite good for the style.

amber color a small off white quickly dissapated head.  I smell almost nothing touches of barley really weak malt.  palate is pretty light.  Very mild flavor sweet barley and carmel.  Overly grainy.. not a great beer.

Thanks Chuck!  Pours to a reddish bronzed color with a thin, rapidly diminishing white head.  I like the color, and thats why a 4 on AP even though the head is nearly non-existent.  The aroma is light.  Toasted breads and a light coffee.  Too light to get a good score.  The flavor is nicely malty.  Sweet breads and a light tea-style hops.  Nice earthy spicyness to it..  Good carbonation and lightly sticky mouthfeel.  Medium bodied.  Im digging this Ofest.

Pours a rich ruby copper like a proper fest should. Aroma of malt, both dry and sweet, slight sour note as well. No sourness in the flavor though, thankfully. A bit drier and less sweet than I had expected from the style -- a bit like a Vienna lager but fundamentally on target. Perfect hop balance -- that is, light application thereof as the style dictates. Not quite as flavorful as other examples of the style. Ive had better, both of the style and from New Glarus. I probably wont make it a point to get a sixer of next years batch, but if I run across it Ill grab some.

This was another beer sampled straight from the bottle in a fishing camp environment.  The appearance I could gather was amber/slight brown.  Its aroma and initial taste were of the sweet malt, and a well balanced toastiness.  Hops were at the right level for a Marzen.  A very good beer.
user_location: Lake in the Hills, Illinois, USA

text: bottle-pours deep amber with a small white head.  not all that aromatic.  toasted grains with a light notes of rainwater and carmel.  the appearance just sux and the body suffers as well-thin and watery.  the flavors are probably the most true to style for the 3 marzens i had on this day.  long toasted grain finish.  i will try it again once i get the chance.

Aroma is semi-sweet fruit, mostly cherry and apricot, with bready malt overtones.  Expansive malt body hints at toffee and caramel with an underbody of slight yeast fruitiness.  Creamy mouthfeel, hinges on buttery, but never syrupy.  The almost nutty finish  is not at all cloying, instead finishing clean and leaving me wanting more.  What a great session brew!

Very attractive dark copper-reddish color.  Aroma is sweet malt, cherries, grass and sugar.  The flavor comes off as a hearty fest beer that is rich and sweet all at the same time.  Body is crisp and has a decent hop flavor towards the end where the cherry flavor comes in, a hint of oak is there as well.  This is a really enjoyable example of the style.
this was okay. nice dark rich color with a rich smell. not quite my cup of tea though

Wow-eee!! Outstanding beer!! This is what an Oktoberfest is all about! Beautiful rich coppery red, nice head, great mouth feel, perfect carbonation, the sweetness and dryness that interplay and make it a definition session beer. Doesnt get any better! Just put on draft at the Bodega downtown La Crosse.
Pours a nice ruby red, little head.  Smells of caramel malt and slight fruity and nutty notes.  Slightly watery in the finish.  Smooth and refreshing.

Coppery brown with a big, quickly diffusing head.  Big nutty aroma with lots of sweet caramel and roasted malt.  Smooth, tihick and full bodied, with nice, light carbonation.  Flavor is a very nice balance of roasted malt, caramel and floral, slightly spicy hops.  The hops linger right through to the finish for a nice ending.  Very enjoyable.

Right after opening the first bottle, I could smell how roasted the taste would be.  Roasted nuts, toast, and caramel all make an impact here.  Body is a bit oily, making for very rich pulls.  Each sip finishes with a crisp taste of hops.  Overall, very nice balance.

Clear caramel pour with very little head.  Aroma picked up some caramel and floral notes, with just some slight spices... with a roasty backbone.  Light-to-medium mouthfeel and powerfully smooth.  Caramel malts provided some sweetness... with a nicely balanced hoppy bitterness on the finish.  Smooth, tasty, and well-balanced.. definitely enjoyed this one!
GTM. Faint aroma. Oktoberfest orange, thin head, large bubble. Malty flavor with a hint of hops. Not bad at all. Very enjoyable. Session qualities. Not very balanced.

On tap @ GTMW.  Clear opulent amber in color with a foamy tan head.  Aroma is caramel, peat, grain and corn husks.  Fuller bodied than anticipated, but a little searing and syrupy.  Caramel and woodsy pecans headline the flavors yet diffuse on the palate rather quickly.  Other elements seem to seep out of a mixed bag of nuts, from hazelnut shells to dry brazils.  Okay, but seemed in cohesive.

Bottle, fresh 2005 release.  Light chewy caramel flavor.  Not getting an increadible spice bouquet, but I do notice some floral notes along with the caramel.  Copper red color with a very thin white head.  Flavor of caramel maltiness with a n abrubt, sweet nutty finish.  Slightly sugary, but not cloying.  I think I notice some minerals in the flavor also.  Light body with a watery texture and a sugary finish.  This is a rerate, original rating was 3.1 after 4 big barleywines.
The only other Oktoberfest Ive had is Leinies.  Let me say that this trumps it hands down.  Great session beer, if the alc. % was lower.  Crisp, piney hops, sweet malts.
Not so Ocktobery, more like the confections of Easter.  Lacks in the robust department, thin and uninteresting.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: (12 oz bottle, obtained in trade with marinaro500, thanks Joe!) I thought I would like this more than I do.  The main reason why Im not overly fond of this Oktoberfest is the sugary, perfumy character the flavor has.  Its moderately malty and caramely in the flavor, but the sweetness tastes sugary.  I discern very little in the way of classic hops or bitterness, but I do get a floral, perfumy flavor and aroma out of this.  The nose is also mildly toasty.  Medium bodied, but the palate just seems a bit watery, especially in the short-lived finish.  Dark amber color is nice.  Pours a medium size off-white head that settles to a thin layer.  Small streams of lace here and there.
Big bubbly head, light brown in color. Nutty, astringent aroma. Taste is sweet and nutty with some sourness and bitterness in the finish. Decent.

Solid amber color with a decent sized off white head. Nice roasted aroma with caramel and toast. Taste is also toasty with caramel and light spices. Nice medium bodied mouthfeel. This is one of the better O-Fest beers Ive had this year. The flavors could use a bit more hoppiness to offset some of the sweet caramel and toffee.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2005 2004  bottle compliments of Footbalm.  I was very interested to try a non-fruit New Glarus, after being very disappointed by the Rasp. Tart.  Pours a clear lightly rusty yellow-copper, small white head, lightly fizzy and mostly dissipating.  Aroma of light roast, moderately dry caramel and some earthy yeast tones.  Flavor starts out with a wonderful, authentic munich malt, caramelly and coppery, with tame, but flavorful yeast notes.  Wonderful progression to the finish, via a spectacularly creamy, smooth body, medium to medium full.  Finish while showcasing the even, balanced malt flavor, has some bitter hops which, while not too bitter, really arent necessary.  This beer could just fade in to the distance with wonderful meaty yeast and malt, dry grainy caramel and hints of rum-raisin and sweet shortbread.  The hops really seem to break up a blissful finish, but I have also been very anti-hops lately, to be fair.  Superb stuff.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2005 Polished rufous. Broken center of foam leaves a thick, tall ring. Toffeeish nose of meaty Munich malt, dates, and marmalade. Rooty malt and smoke hints. Fuzzy, tight spritz to the carbonation. Tangy Munich blankets the palate with notes of toffee and roast. Vaguely fruity with hints of toffeed apple and dates. Lushly malty and bready, yet beautifully dry and well-attenuated, with a pleasantly spicy hop spine and anise hints, which relentlessly hold the sweetness at bay. Grainy malt and gentle roast astringency punctuate the dry firmness of the body. Finishes shyly hoppy with lastingly rich  date and bready malt flavors. Rock solid Märzen that would be perfect with a touch more hops.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Clear reddish-brown body with a thick off-white head.  Malty nose with nut shells and roasty caramel.  "Incredible spice boquet"?  Is the dry nuttiness supposed to be spicy?  One-dimensional flavor that tastes like roasted malt.  Light malt roast and leafy hops in the finish.  About what I expect out of an Oktoberfest: a malty, unexciting beer.  Id rate it lower but at least it has an assertive flavor.

A dark amber color with a moderate head. The aroma is caramel and nuts. The flavor is very malty and somewhat sweet with a nice hazelnut, caramel, and apple flavor. This one is a little higher up in the ABV dept than many oktoberfests Ive had but you cant taste any alcohol. A nicely done beer. Facto is the man!

clear copper, nice off white head.  spicy, earthy, fruity/jelly candy aroma.  clean smooth flavour with soft juicy malts, fruit and a hint of alcohol.  toast and spicy hop in the finish.  quite tasty.

Bottled. Acquired in a trade with joeybgood. Thanks Joe! Copper body with a small whitish head. Nose is nice and malty with pleasant fruitiness, caramel, and grains. Taste is rich and malty iwht lighter caramel, some fainter biscuity notes, and grains with light fruits.  Body is medium to nea full. Finsihes with lighter fruit, caramel, maltiness and grains. Good beer! Would be a great session beer.

12 oz bottle: great pour: golden bubbles fall throughout the brightly bronzed body, full sandy coloured head forms on top.  Brisk, cane sugar aroma with a soft malt bill filled with sweet raisins, lush red apples, and toffee.  Rich, nutty malt flavours, but without too much depth.  Quick, sweet palate that is slightly grainy and toasted.  Not my favorite Oktoberfest flavour, but a great aroma and fairly decent overall.

Nice clear orange amber with a quickly dissapearing off white head.  The aroma is malty, nutty and clean.  It is quite distinctive and crisp.  The flavor is similarly malty and crisp.  Good grains and there are some hops providing slight bitterness around the edges while maintaining a nice creamyness in the feel and finish.  Thanks to JCaprioti
Orange in color, with a quickly disappearing head. Aromas of grain and hops. Flavor is grainy as well, with some sweetness and a light body.
Red color with little head.  Grainy aroma.  The taste is like that of a feed mill.  Interesting, and the direction of grainy is what Id want in an Oktoberfest, but this is a little over the top.

Bottle pours a fairly clear dark copper, small whispy white head, good carbonation, with decent lacing. &nbsp Strong grainy & oat aroma. &nbsp Perhaps a bit biscuity as well. &nbsp Quite biscuity on the flavor, with a heavy graininess. &nbsp It is also rather herbish. &nbsp Okay body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Finishes strong on the herbs, oats, and maybe some bark. &nbsp This one is WAY too earthy for me. &nbsp Thanks goes out to heemer77 for the trade!
Red Coloring.  Okt. Spice Aroma.. Kinda Watery Overall.  Some Hops and a Bit Dry at the End... Decent But Not Wonderful.
Pours deep red/amber with a berry and spice aroma. Small off white head. Good mouthfeel. Apples and spice. Cloves in particular. Chewy bread malts. Clean, smooth, and roasty. Very well made beer.

pours an amber red color with a slightly off white creamy head...it looks delicious sitting here.  malty sweet aroma with some bread and hazelnut mixed in.  Creamy body, not too overly sweet but can certainly notice the malt, nuttiness is apparent as well as some estery flavors.  Very tasty Octoberfest compared to some of the others ive tried.
Aroma :Light , velvety sweet alcoholic hints  . Sweet soft malts , pleasant spicy finish . Medium bodied. Very clean, nicely balanced. Full rounded . Good full malts . Nice one.

When I think about the style, this beer will come to mind.  It is made to style.  Aroma of sweet malt(carmel) and noble hops.    Translucent amber color smal white head.  Syrupy bodied.  Sweet carmelly finish.  Thanks, Jason

Decent sized off-white and creamy head. Nice clear, slightly dark amber body. Sweet malty aroma... interesting. Cant tell what it smells like. Its sweet bread dough I think, with a little bit of spice. Flavor allows a slight chocolate malt hint to break through the bread overtone. Slight hops wrap the tongue in the finish. Pretty good.

Poured bright red/ambe with thin tan head...smelled of malts and bread...taste was still a little thin, but hops were present to balance all of the malts out (unlike most Octoberfests)...dont get me wrong, it wasnt hoppy, just balanced for a change...
Stale malt.  Not much going on here.  Needed a bit more of the cookie, dough flavors to kick through.
This beer poured a nice clear amber color with a thin white head.  The flavor was malty, bready, and medium-full bodied.  The finish was a bit sweet and this was a great Oktoberfest.
pleasant sweet malty aroma --- good off white head --- semi-licorice and toasted flavor with some sweetness -- nice finish -- would deffinately have it again

Reddish Copper, no head. Toasty and fruit aroma, like red plum jam on toast. Rich and full bodied/ Peppery, Herbaland woodsy. Nice blending of sweet and bitter, very satisfying beer. Thanks to Marinaro500 for this trade!

Nice clear amber brown with thick off white head. Nice sweet malt nose with roasted flavors. Medium weight with dry finish. Toasted malt flavors with slight cherry note. Decent octoberfest offering form NG.

Another well-made brew from NG.  Beautiful amber color, but worthless head.  Nice lightly sweetish, earthy aroma.  Toasty grain flavors, black-tea tannins.  Lightish but satisfying palate.  Great session lager.

I actually went to the brewery in New Glarus Wisconsin and sampled this one at one of the local "Swiss-Colony" taverns in town. Very fresh-tasting beer with a nice aroma of roasted malt. The taste is very crisp and clean with a slight bitter, toasted-almond aftertaste. Makes for a great beer to drink in the late fall or early winter months.

Appearance: clear, bright red color, good, 1/4" white head.
Subtle aromatics, malty, yes, but not scraming about it. Some fruit notes, a touch coppery, and a bit toasted. 
Taste: nice little hops up front, soon settling back, very tasty. Medium bodied, lingering finish. Quite a different Oktoberfest, goes farther in some ways than others, more restrained in other ways. Still, owns its own unique complexity, less overtly malty-sweet. A bit metallic in the taste, with a very subtle, snappy malty flavor, ultimately crisp and dry in the end.
Staghorn embodies a beautiful contradiction, a malty beer thats not treacly-sweet. In a class of its own.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2005 Bottle at Nicks bar in Madison. Tried again from civ, thanks for the bottle. Has a nice ,medium amber coloring. A small khaki colored head and little carbonation. A very malty nose and some old leaves. There is also some toffee. The taste is also sweet and malty. Has some vinous character, grass and fresh bread. There is also a little bit of caramel. Well done for the style.
New Glarus take on the Octoberfest.  A reddish/copper colored, heavier malted beer. Taste is spicy and and full. A nice take on a great style.

Orange-amber color with a thin, short-lived, white head. Smells of heavy malt, newspapers, autumn leaves and brazil nuts. However, as the beer warms it smells exactly like a bag of dry dog food. Mouthfeel is medium to full for this style. Taste is hoppy and a little watery slathered upon a rich, somewhat fruity, malt backbone. Aftertaste is dry and remniscent of soda water. Overall a decent marzen.

Cloudy copper pour with a thin white head. Nice malty aroma. Some spice lingers in the background. Pretty smooth taste. Malty, spicy, smooth balance. Nice brew! Thanks to Jeremy (jgb9348) for bringing this down!!

Clear copper coloured body with orange highlights and a thin off-white head. Aroma of pumpkin, malt, nutmeg, some fruit and hardly any hops. Medium-bodied; Strong spicey flavour with a big malt background and little else. Aftertaste has a bunch of nutmeg flavour and a dry feeling. Overall, a great beer to try with everyone-I got this twelve ounce bottle in a trade with BBB63, and sampled it on 26-May-2004.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2004 A very rich, amber-orange colored feast of malt. Malt flavor is tilted heavily to roasted and toasted aroma and flavor.  Slight chestnut and acorns, maybe even a bit of soft smoke.  Malty but not sweet.  Huge body, only a hint of spice, big malt taste.  Not a lot of head, but lingers.  Have had few USA Marzens that are this good.
A fine all around beer with good head nice taste and aroma. A bit to weak for me. A good beer but not great.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2004 This is an excellent Oktoberfest. It has a beautiful amber shine with a just off white head. Smooth palate with just the right maltiness. Excellent finish. As good a Paulaner. Anybody got a recipe for this one?

Bottle pours a clear copper color with an off white head and very little lace.  The aroma consists of apple and malt.  The flavor starts out sweet and malty and finishes with more of the fruit quality.  The palate is not overly rich or light and with some nice carbonation in the small bubble tingly sense.  Overall, this is a good Marzen and will look for it again next time I am across the border...

Running out of New Glarus beers to try for the first time but this is one I missed so far.  Poured with a big head, and a fruity smell.  First taste sweet and copperry taste.  Aftertaste is fruity kind of a cider taste to it.  Would recommend a six pack to anyone.
Nice smooth fest beer.  Lots of sweet malts, but not overly caramel tasting.  Tastes like some winter spices snuck in there too.  Finish was o.k. - I'd prefer a pinch more hops there.

Solid darkish copper color with a small puffy off-white head that sticks around a while eventually fading to nothing as its consumed and leaves sheets of lace that dispear fast to stick in webby lines and spots. Wonderful toasted aroma on this, touch of caramel and light floral dried hops, very crisply toasted with a hint of ripe fruity-like sweetness reminescent of a sour bread dough. Really becomes a sniffer as it warms. Taste is a nice toasty, lightly sweet mix of maltyness, very solid through and through. Sweetness is strong but subdued in its presense over an amazing and great little toastyness, some thinner caramel sits in the back with some light herbal/floral dried hops setting up the finish to end with a nice mellow crispness and light lingering sweetness. Medium body feel, lightly creamy aspect and a lovely finish. A very nice O'fest beer that goes down with ease. A new favorite to keep around, top notch and a cut above alot of the mish-mashy O'fest brews that every brewery seems to make. This one is done right. Great job New Glarus!

Sort of an off-slightly rotten apple smell.  Very little head and the beer wasn't as red as advertised.  The flavor, however, delivers nicely.  Rich, sweet on the tongue and has cinnamony qualities.  Crisp finish and very nice.
not much head, vibrant, crystal clear copper body.  roastey and caramely.  a nice octoberfest.  a good malt presence all around.  a sweet toasty body with a slightly nutty finish.

Reddish brown hue with little head. Sweet roasted malt aroma with hints of sublime fruit and earthy grains. Taste was initially sweet with caramel and toffee tones. Some undertone of a lively acidic nature crept upon the palate. A touch of allspice upon the finish. A medium-bodied brew with a soft mouthfeel. Quaffable marzen that could use a very slight increase of (saaz) hops to add a crisp edge.
Orange color from the bottle with a thin white head and a dusty grain nose.  Sweet grainy malt flavors.  Enjoyable Octoberfest.
I would like to give this one a few more tries, but on a first tasting I found it a more-than-acceptable Octoberfest.

Thin amber body, light head. Toasty aroma. Notes of caramel in the malt, slightly toasty/woody. Some sweetness in the finish, not very hoppy, resulting in somewhat of a thin finish. Well balanced and enjoyable although not incredibly complex.
Reddish amber with a small non-lasting head.  Caramel malt aroma with a hint of coffee.  A dry roasted malt taste, slightly fruity and sweet.  Nice but a little sweet for me.

Bottled. Reddish amber. The crystal malt flavour is dominating the beer. Chewy mouthfeel. Pleasant, but one-dimensional. I've never really accepted octoberfest beers made with crystal malt, but this one is pretty good.
Bottle.  Amber with a laced head.  Malt at the front with some spice at the finish.  Rather weak.  Thanks to Nuffield for the bottle.
Malty sweetness, lively carbonation, but a friend and I both said, "we cant taste anything."  Decent body and color but nothing to impress.
A very drinkable beer.  Warm and spicey with a nice balance of malt.

My thanks to Pjones6738 for this one. Very passable Marzen. Deep dark amber with a medium beige head. Strong malt aroma. Rich malt and caramel flavor with a nicely spiced finish. This is one of the better New Glarus beers I have tried so far. On a side note, I have really liked all of New Glarus labels so far.

Just terrific.  A mild, malty Okto that doesnt try to bowl you over with spice or hops.  Its a terrific session Marzen that can be consumed in quantity.  New Glarus is an excellent brewery, and this is further proof.

What an aroma. If we were rating soley on aroma this would be a top 25 beer. Sadly the flavor doesnt live up to the promise of the aroma. The body is pretty thin and the flavor has some of the malt sweetness i love but fails to deliver completely. Not a bad oktoberfest but not stellar either.
Very sweet and smooth.  Bright copper colored with a small head.  A very drinkable and good Oktoberfest.
Decent Oktoberfest, somewhat bland in taste?no real punch to it.  Oh well, when you live in the state of awesome beers, occasionally you get one that is just good.
Good amber color, spicy malt aroma. Mmm...nice sweet malt, with just a little hop bitterness to balance it. Seems to get more bitter as it warms. Suprisingly dry. Very enjoyable beer.
Nice amber brown color.  A little too much bubble gum flavor for my liking.  Not as much head as advertised.  Aroma was somewhat spicy.  Pass on this one if you are looking for a good octoberfest.
Dark amber color with a thick light tan head.  Very malty aroma. Flavors that follow.  This one has improved over the years, but still seems to lack the toasty flavors I enjoy in an oktoberfest.

Beautiful orange/red; Head was THIN; very faint malt aroma.
Light on the tongue, Fluffy. Not tons of character. I really expected more from this brewery; Shame on you New Glarus.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2016 (2016) First one of these Ive had in probably - 4 or 5 years at the least.  Poured at a bit above fridge temp into a New Glarus pils glass, and waited for a while for the bounteous white foam to die.  It leaves thick Escher-like lacing (does that make sense?  No?  too bad) above the clear amber body....big malty nose, surprisingly not that sweet but quite full with light caramel and a fair amount of toasted character...moderately sweet front, nicely balanced caramel malts and paler varieties along with a hint of smokiness and burnt quality, just a touch oily in the mouthfeel; some pepperiness to finish, a bit low on the carbonation scale for the style I think, which is fine as its not too thick and never syrupy.  Overall still a very solid rendition; original rate was 3.3 but I feel justified in a bump up of a point.


(2001)The nose is the best part of this, big, malty, vinous and almost bock-like.  Appearance is nice and orange, but with little head and seemingly thin.  Flavor confirms this; some good maltiness typical of the style, but little complexity or spiciness, little hops and somewhat bland on the finish.  Ok, but not up to the brewers high standards.
I wanted to like this more than I did.  Sweetish with off malt flavors.
Superb, the best of the American Oktoberfest beers.
Good Oktoberfest.
Nice aroma and clean crisp flavors are noteworthy for this beer.  The finish is a little too bitter, otherwise very good and close to the German Oktoberfest flavor.
